title: Assessing the Risk of Transfer of Microorganisms at the International Space Station Due to Cargo Delivery by Commercial Resupply Vehicles
background: With increasing interplanetary missions, robust protocols are needed to protect extraterrestrial planets from contamination by terrestrial life forms. This study compares commercial resupply vehicle (CRV) microbiome with ISS microbiome to understand contamination risks.
objective: To determine if CRV systems could be a source of microbial contamination of the ISS by characterizing microbial diversity of CRV prior to launch
methods: Samples from internal surfaces and ground support equipment of three CRV missions were analyzed using cultivation assays, ATP assays, qPCR, and shotgun metagenome sequencing. Comparison was made with previously reported ISS microbiome data.
results: CRV internal surfaces were clean with order of magnitude fewer microbes than ground support equipment. CRV1 had larger microbial population than subsequent missions. Metagenome comparison revealed significant differences between CRV and ISS microbiomes, with CRV microbiomes being negligible part of ISS environmental microbiome.
conclusion: Cleaning protocols for CRV surfaces are highly effective in controlling contaminating microbial population during cargo transfer to ISS, showing very little risk of microorganism transfer via CRV transport.

key_techniques: qPCR for 16S rRNA and ITS regions
Cultivation on R2A, BA, and PDA media
Statistical analysis (MWW test, NMDS, diversity indices)
key_outcomes: CRV internal surfaces had 10x fewer microbes than GSE
Only 9 microbial species common between CRV and ISS
CRV3 showed no detectable microbial growth
Significant statistical differences between CRV and ISS microbiomes
extracted_entities.confidence: Validated through multiple molecular techniques and statistical analysis
gaps: Some cultured microorganisms not detected in metagenomics
Strain-level tracking needed for fungal isolates
Seasonal variations in sampling not accounted for
opportunities: Protocol application for future planetary missions
Application to lunar and Mars mission cargo

learning_notes.note: Commercial resupply vehicles showed significantly cleaner internal surfaces compared to ground support equipment, with CRV1 having 1.3×10⁵ to 2.8×10⁶ CFU/m² on GSE surfaces but only 1.8×10⁴ CFU/m² on internal surfaces, demonstrating effective contamination control during cargo loading procedures.

The study employed multiple validation methods including ATP assays showing 15-30% viable microorganisms on internal CRV1 surfaces, qPCR detecting 10⁵-10⁸ 16S rRNA gene copies/m², and PMA treatment distinguishing intact cells, providing comprehensive microbial burden assessment.

Metagenomic analysis revealed distinct microbial communities between CRV and ISS, with CRV dominated by Proteobacteria (32-95%), Firmicutes (10-40%), and Actinobacteria (11-21%), while ISS was dominated by human-associated microbes like Enterobacteriaceae and Staphylococcaceae.

Only 9 microbial species were common between CRV and ISS environments out of 420 total species detected, with CRV microbiomes constituting a negligible part (statistically significant difference, p=0.000162) of the ISS environmental microbiome.

Cleaning protocols proved highly effective, with CRV3 showing no detectable microbial growth in any assays, and cleaning timing (24 hours vs day-of sampling) affecting microbial recovery, highlighting the importance of protocol standardization.

The study identified potential opportunistic pathogens including Staphylococcus pasteuri, Exophiala xenobiotica, and Phialemonium dimorphosporum in CRV samples, though these were not detected in ISS samples, demonstrating effective containment.

Statistical analyses including Mann-Whitney-Wilcoxon tests, NMDS ordination, and diversity indices (Shannon, Simpson, Chao1) consistently showed significant differences between CRV and ISS microbiomes, validating the minimal contamination risk.
